reviewText:
They Bleed Pixels is a gleefully bloody little action-platformer.  The player gets their kicks by controlling the fountain of blood in the shape of a little girl that is the protagonist, but the game itself will also gets its kicks in the form of all the cutting, stabbing, and impaling that it does to the player.

This game's greatest feature is that it's hard, but in the best kind of way.  The controls are extremely intuitive and always spot on, and every death (there will be many) feels justified and avoidable.  The player must master the controls quickly, because the difficulty quickly ramps up and stays there.  Luckily, the difficulty is offset by the highly enjoyable combat, wonderfully gory pixel graphics, and the fact that most of the harder challenges are completely optional.  A competent mastery of the controls is necessary to complete the game properly, but the completion of the deadliest (and most frustrating) challenges is never a requirement.

The game is nail-bitingly difficult, but its relative shortness and the freshness of the content means that it doesn't overstay its welcome.  If you are looking for a dark and necrotic twist on finger gymnastics, give They Bleed Pixels a try!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I love twitch platformers, so when this game recently went on sale it was a must-buy item for me. I have to say, this game deserves to be placed right next to SMB on the twitch platforming pedestal.

The controls are spot on, tight, and a feel exactly the way you'd want them to, especially on an Xbox-style controller.

This game, not satisfied being a reskinned SMB adds a couple new mechanics, most notably the large focus on combat and combos. If you want to hit the highscore boards in this game, you'll need to not only platform with dead-on precision, and quickly, but do so while sluaghtering lovecraftian enemies in stylish combos.

The controls, the mechanics, and the setting all make this game top-of-class, I highly recommend this game to fans of the genre.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: This is a relatively solid platformer with some interesting quirks. It is somewhat similiar to Super Meat Boy...but that isn't entirely right. It shares SMB's percision, tight controls, and OCD for making the exactly right move at the exactly right time. You also get a parade of your deaths, though not in the same way. Conversely, TBP is more complex, due to its larger range of moves, and less focused on long stretches of hair tearing, due to it's more lenient save mechanism (the difficulty is still pretty brutal though). Similarly, the stages are longer, but the game is shorter. For replay value, there are over 150 achievements, and three (soon 4) bonus levels. Notably, the achievements actually do things (unlock art, most of which is pretty nice). Visuals are nice and simple, with some very cool effects. The music is nice too, if chippy.\n\nOverall, I enjoy this one, and would recommend it.

reviewText:
Though simple, the art style and animations are absolutely beautiful. Having this helps when youre staring at the same thing for how many hours  due to dying so much. The soundtrack compliments the game as well, and though freaking difficult, you still wanna play more and more.
The controls are simple and not complicated whatsoever. With very few buttons you're able to do a range of diferent attacks. Though i have to admit, on multiple occassions i had attempted to, say, just do a quick punch, though what happened was a quick dash - ultimately leading to my death. Whether it be into a pile of spikes or off the ledge. It just adds to the difficulty of the game, though usually is no problem.

There a different factors of this game that remind me of Super Meat Boy, and both games are great. Got ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at both, but nevertheless, theyre still really fun.
I'd recommend this to anyone up for a challenge. Youre going to die whilst playing this game. A lot. But no matter how many times you may, or how angry you get, its all worth it. If you're a sucker for platformers, definitely pick this up. Have fun dying!

reviewText: They Bleed Pixels is a really rad little game. A platformer/brawler hybrid inspired by the many works of H.P. Lovecraft where you stab, kick, launch, and combo your way through eldritch abominations, TPB stars a young girl thrust into a strange and unusual dreamworld adventure every night after discovering a ritual book used by the headmaster of the Troubled Youth's school she is attending. It really is an absolute blast to play, combining elements of a brawler or fighting game such kicks, stabs, launching enemies into the air for air combos, and guard breaking with platforming reminiscient of games like Super Meat Boy, producing all the creative possibilities that combination can yield. The enemies and the environment are out to get you, but you can turn back on them just as easily. If you need a good platformer fix, or want a thrilling, Lovecraftian beat 'em up with challenge to match, absolutely pick up this game.

reviewText:
I've used the character for this game as my avatar pretty much since I joined Steam and I just realized that I never wrote a review for it. This game is fun. Hard as all hell, but fun. I would honestly recommend this game to anyone itching for a fun challenge. I don't see myself ever going for the top of the leaderboards or anything on this one, but at the end of a level I honestly feel like I'm accomplished something, and that's nice.

I love the design of this game. Ya' it's the over done pixelated motif, but the colors and all around art direction of the game makes up for that. If the game were done some other way it would probably lose some of it's charm if anything. The game play is really nice too. It's quick, responsive, and challenging. Generally speaking I can tell when I've screwed up and how I screwed up. When I keep slipping up it just gives me more practice the next time. Usually within a couple of goes I can get an area memorized well enough to get past it.

The down side to this might be that if the pixel-art type game isn't your thing you might not like this one. The other downside being that some of the enemies are a little annoying (specifically the flying squids). They're so small that they're very hard to hit and most of the time just trying to trick them into hitting a pointy part of the level worked better. Which is cool, but tough when theres multiple squids on the screen. Neither one of these is much of a downside though.

I love this game, and I'm ashamed it took me so long to review the game. It really is a blast to play and even if I never complete it I still have fun with it.

reviewText:
Value for Entertainment: $3.50

They Bleed Pixels is for hardcore platforming junkies only. It becomes hair-pullingly difficult in its second half, and if you're not prepared to memorize enemy patterns and master every element you're not going to get much out of it. For them, it is recommended during a Steam sale.

I poured about six hours into the game before quitting (for the time being). There are many better 'tough' platformers available (Super Meat Boy and Blood of the Werewolf come to mind), but if you've already payed through those this is pretty decent.

Just prepare for premature baldness.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Very good platformer with a story that is told in a very cryptic way using comic-like panels with no dialogue.  Frustratingly hard but awesome combat and puzzles.

Rest of the review:

They Bleed Pixels is about as awesome as a 2D platformer can get.  It has good music, retro sound effects, lots of pixel blood, and danger around every corner.  It also has smooth controls and combat that feels satisfying.

The combat involves learning which moves to use on which enemies and how and where to strike those enemies.  The moves include kicking, stabbing, and launching.  You can kick enemies into the air to either juggle them or launch them into environmental dangers.  Your moves also allow you to jump, double jump, slide, slam, and rush through obstacles in each level.  You can hit enemies into other enemies and use enemies as part of level-based puzzles.

The controls are fairly simple and very comfortable.  You do not need a gamepad.  The movement on keyboard isn't much different from a gamepad, but I frequently chose to use my Xbox 360 controller due to the joystick being a lot more controllable than WASD keys, allowing me to more easily control the character's left and right movement speed.

The game features a lot of blood in pixel art form.  I like the style of this game and welcome the blood, but blood shouldn't make or break this game.  The only reason I mention it is I feel that some people may wonder why the blood effect exists.  It isn't realistic, it just looks cool when you impale enemies.

The visuals of the game are very eye-catchy and fun in my opinion.  The player character is lovable due mostly to the cutesy art style.  The pixel art is animated fairly well.

Sound production quality is pretty high. The music, though I hardly remember it since I didn't listen to much of it, is very good.

I got this game outside of Steam and later got a Steam copy, so don't take the lack of time investment as a sign of how long the game will last.  It is a lengthy game that I never actually completed.

reviewText: Great art style and music. Combat isn't very deep, but helps to break up the more difficult parts (hint: clear all enemies before placing a check point). Not for everyone, reading some of the other reviews has told me this. Finally getting one of the precision areas perfect is immensly satisfying and is the reason I'm still playing it.\n\nThis game takes time and practise. The levels are long and will sometimes seem impossible. Sometimes it's just a game of memory. And the knock back system can sometimes be infuriating. (SAW BLAAAADES!!!!) But I love all this. I like getting told No
recommended:
come back tomorrow when you've slept on it."

My only gripe with this game is the so call "place your own checkpoint system". It's not really. Large sections of the game are designed so that placing a checkpoint is impossible. It works more like; get enough points so you can place a checkpoint when the developers want you to.

Like I said
hoursPlayed: not for everyone. But if you enjoy getting beaten to a pulp only to rise again with more experience so that you can once and for all consider yourself a hardcore gamer
voteText: then I can't recomment this game enough to you."

reviewText: This game can sometimes seem infuriatingly difficult but really there are little environment puzzles to solve that once you figure out seem really obvious. The game mechanics are pretty simple but allow for a lot of variety in puzzle solving. The art style as the name suggests is cute pixelated gore. The upbeat chiptunes soundtrack adds to the fun (if you're into that style) and makes it feel fast. Dying over and over in the same place in this game is not nearly as rage-inducing as in lots of other games, because you can restart quickly, and because you can (sort of) choose where to set checkpoints. The only issue I have with the gameplay is sometimes there aren't strong visual cues where to go to progress, I basically just jump off a ledge and hope I don't die. Or maybe I just suck at navigating. Really fun game overall.

reviewText:
First time I tried to play this game.... it crashed.    ...
After that, played some of the game, but it would randomly slow down for no reason. That was fixed once I disabled v-sync (♥♥♥♥ v-sync, I have yet to find a ♥♥♥♥ing game where it is actually useful and doesn't erect a barrier on enjoying the game).

Once we're over all of the issues, the game itself is short and fun, although nothing too innovative. Some areas were really annoying to get through. The 3-hits system is useless half of the time, when you get hit, chances are you'll get bounced around and get the other 2 hits without even getting a chance to recover.
I hate slippery floor mechanics, but they are part of the game and thankfully they are used sensibly. There were a few points in the game that if the developers had used slippery floor as well, I would have had uninstalled the game, right there.
The controls feel a bit weird but you can get used to them. The endgame stuff is very frustrating, as to be expected. It's not IWBTG-tier ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, but expect to rage a bit...
It feels like the hitboxing is crap. Sometimes you can get away with almost headbutting spikes, but get just a bit close to a saw, not even touching it, and you'll get juggled around the map.
There are some extras that you can unlock by getting achievements... I say ♥♥♥♥ that, getting through those stages without dying is tougher than you think it is >_>

I'd say, grab this game in a sale and give it a try.

reviewText:
So fun, but so hard.

Everything about this game is perfect, except for the repetitiveness of the enemies and the limited story.

That's intentional, because where this game shines is the perfectly crafted gameplay: every pixel of every level seems carefully considered to produce just the right gameplay challenge. The story is just window dressing, and the enemies are just set pieces.

Still, about 3/4 through the game I came to feel more like I was playing extremely well-designed fan levels than a full game, because of the lack of development in the scenery and enemies.

Does what it intends to perfectly, but I kindof wish it intended to do more. Would buy again.

reviewText: They Bleed Pixels marked my second try at a current gen hardcore platformer.  To preface my review, I must say that I am not a young gamer anymore, and these types of games pose a huge difficulty for me.  Honestly, I was never very good at video games, and I'm not even sure why I torture myself.  I suppose I couldn't resist satisfying my curiosity after suffering through about 30% of Super Meat Boy, seeing how this game looks much more interesting, with more visual appeal and a better sound track.  To cut to the chase, this game is HARD!!  I died several hundred times on a few of the levels, and yes, it was infuriating at times, but not b/c it required pixel perfect precision like SMB, but rather b/c what I needed to accomplish always seemed just slightly out of reach of my rickety old hands.  The game does allow you do make your own checkpoints once your blood meter fills up, having killed enough enemies, and it is a joy to perform simple combos and find different ways to kill your foes.  Just know that there will be times you will want to throw your controller (try not to hit your big shiny flatscreen), blame the controls for your screw-ups, and you will curse this game repeatedly.  The levels are lengthy; so it's not so much a continuous stream of bite-sized levels like MeatBoy, it's more akin to Electronic Super Joy in that regards, but not quite as unforgiving.  The squids are a horribly infuriating, cheap enemy, and at times, the knife wielding ninjas (?) can seem a bit unfair, but if you're into hardcore ultra-difficult platformers, they will probably seem like standard affair.  One cool aspect is that there are several bonus levels that you can unlock, and I believe one of them was unlocked by default.  I didn't do the Ponycorn bonus content; I chose one of the others that I unlocked and that was enough for me.  I really liked the game, but it's very stressful for me to play, so I had no intention of doing all of the bonus stuff.  Some of the artwork that you can unlock is very good, too.  Unless you're a completionist, you may want to check online to see which slots unlcok which art pieces, b/c the styles vary and I found that the photorealistic ones were more preferable to my taste.  Now, I will nto spoil the ending, but just be warned that it is rather anti-climactic.  This game is more about the journey than the destination, and it was definitely worth the few dollars I paid to buy this game on sale.  Hopefully it won't take most people the 31 hours it took me to complete it.  As angry as the game made me, my eagerness to see new levels kept me pushing through, b/c the art style is really interesting, and far more preferable to Super Meat Boy or Electronic SuperJoy.

reviewText: I have a bit of a strange relationship with this game. I love it, but I hate it. It's great fun to play, but when I do play it, I want to throw my computer across the room. reviewText:
Uses the tried and tested gameplay of one button mashing combos that might get stale for some people after a while but all in all it's a cute little game. The Save Sigil is a very innovative game mechanic and it allows you to decide when you want to save the game.

Would you save now and be safe but run the risk of not getting enough energy for a Save Sigil later at a more important point? Or would you brave through the enemies awaiting you and use the Save Sigil at a more important point later in the stage?

What would you choose?
